title: What group of elements has atoms with two valence electrons? - Quora

response.answer_text: “Group”? It’s clear that this is one of those high school trivia questions, because the obvious answer is the Group IIA elements, the divalent cations like magnesium and calcium. But that’s not exactly a complete answer, is it?  (image adapted from Periodic Table with Charges - 118 Elements) If you look at the image above, where I’ve circled some of the notable ones in a magenta oval, you see that there are more elements with two valence electrons to give, and in fact all of the early transition metals from manganese to zinc all seem to be able to give two valence electrons. In fact, all of the group IIB elements seem to have this same property, so if I may be so bold, I’d suggest that both group IIA and IIB have two valence electrons. But that’s not all- you have europium as well, and lead. So it’s not just “groups” that have this property, but a smattering of others outside the groups as well. And, of course, you need to consider the fact that mercury is… mercurial, and can be either +1 or +2. And i think I left out one or two examples… can you find others above? The point here is that “valency” is a incomplete theory of how molecules form. When you begin looking at how more complicated molecules form, you see instances of partial or fluctuating valency, partial charges, hypervalency, and a whole bestiary of new properties. The valence of atoms is just a first degree approximation of the underlying properties of atoms, and my advice is not to get too hung up on the exact answering of such a question. …unless of course, this is one of those high school quizzes you get, in which case if you start tacking on “…and europium!” you’re likely to flunk for being a smartass. But understand that these things aren’t cut and dry rules and doctrines that you can quote chapter and verse as you get older and wiser.

response.answer_text: Group -2 elements have 2 valence electrons in their valence shell.These group elements are commonly called as Alkaline Earth metals.  Some examples are Berrylium,Calcium,Strontium,Barium,Magnesium etc.
